taxonomicnotes: Schilbe intermedius Ruppell, 1832 was described from the lower Nile River in Egypt. As presently recognised this species has a wide African distribution from the Phongolo River in KwaZulu-Natal north to the Nile and across into parts of west Africa. Taxonomic examination of isolated populations using new techniques e.g. DNA sequencing is needed.  Schilbe intermedius seems closely related to S. urano-scopus and these species are sympatric in several hydrographic basins.
rationale: This species has a wide distribution, with no known major widespread threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Although it faces some local threats, particularly in eastern Africa, it has also been assessed regionally as Least Concern for central, eastern, north eastern, southern and western Africa.
assessor: Bills, R., Cambray, J., Getahun, A.,  Lalèyè, P., Marshall, B., Moelants, T., Ntakimazi, G., Olaosebikan, B.D. & Tweddle, D.
evaluator: Snoeks, J., Tweddle, D., Getahun, A., Lalèyè, P., Paugy, D., Zaiss, R., Fishar, M.R.A & Brooks, E.
